Award.AwardTitle: EAGER: Human-Team-Machine Interaction in Emergency Response

Division.LongName: Div Of Civil, Mechanical, & Manufact Inn

Award.AbstractNarration:
A critical challenge to emergency response in critical infrastructures is understanding how decisions are made by the incident management team (IMT), which serves as the nerve center guiding the overall response effort. At the core of decision-making in such large and dynamic teams is team cognition, which in emergency response can be viewed as the responders' ability to form a "common operating picture." The goal of this EArly-concept Grant for Exploratory Research (EAGER) project is to examine the relationship of cognition to individual and team performance in IMTs. While it is difficult to study actual IMTs at work, high-fidelity simulation facilities place responders in exercises that replicate real-world emergency events. This research leverages one such facility, the Emergency Operations Training Center (EOTC) operated by the Texas A&M Engineering Extension Service (TEEX), a world leader in emergency responder training, to study IMTs without the need to collect data during actual incidents (which would be both impractical and undesirable given the urgency of real events). Based on observations and recordings, the researchers will conduct a qualitative analysis of team communication and build social networks representing interactions among team members, which collectively form cognition in the team, according to recent findings. The researchers will break the team's work into its constituent elements and examine how each element makes use of key technologies. Because the work involves performance-oriented interventions, it will lead to improved responder training and thus will contribute to reduced loss of life and property during catastrophic events. The EOTC will be able to use research findings to guide redesign of software and training tools. As leaders in emergency management, EOTC instructors and staff are in regular communication with policymakers, enabling them to translate research outcomes into actionable information to improve the U.S. National Preparedness Guidelines, the National Incident Management System (NIMS), and state and local equivalents.

This research seeks to characterize the influence of interactions among humans, teams, and technologies on individual and team performance in high-pressure, time-constrained environments such as emergency response. In these situations, the IMT supports first responders from a centralized incident command post (ICP). The IMT solves complex safety-critical problems under high time pressure and ubiquitous information flow, so the team's ability to receive, process, and share information is essential to successful outcomes. Building on the view that team cognition is inseparable into individual cognition, the research focuses on the team as a singular entity, termed the "aggregate team artifact." Unlike traditional human-machine interaction (HMI) studies, this research examines two new complementary concepts: human-team interaction (HTI) and team-machine interaction (TMI). While HTI focuses on individuals' interactions with the aggregate team artifact, TMI applies HMI methods to the team entity's interactions with tools and technologies. The researchers will conduct a focused study to explore and validate HTI and TMI. During exercises involving actual emergency responders in high-fidelity ICP simulations, the work of the Planning subteam will be recorded and transcribed. Beginning with grounded theory analysis of transcripts, the researchers will categorize HTI and TMI content, build team communication networks to devise metrics of HTI, adapt task analysis techniques to assess TMI, and relate metrics of HTI and TMI to individual and team performance. This work will make fundamental contributions to human factors (HTI and TMI to complement HMI), social and organizational psychology (team cognition in real-world high-pressure settings), and systems engineering (characterization of teams as complex systems). By providing a proof-of-concept for HTI and TMI, this exploratory study will serve as an initial step toward the creation of an integrated predictive model for emergency response.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The domain of this proposal was Incident Management Teams (IMTs) that direct and coordinate responses to disasters. The objective of this proposal was to characterize and understand interactions between humans and technologies in IMTs and how those interactions may influence these teams? abilities to address complex safety-critical problems under high time pressure and constant information flow. Toward this end, this project has resulted in two major scientific gains that have significant intellectual merit. 

 

The first contribution is the advancement of knowledge regarding the essential elements of interactions between IMT members as well as information management activities using a novel method developed in this project. The method?referred to as the Interaction Episode Analysis (IEA)? is designed to capture and describe complex team performance emerging from interactions between human operators and technical components. The results from the analysis enable comparisons between different observations (which has been historically difficult to do with a level of granularity that supported empirical research) and identification of challenges faced by the teams in managing incident information and adaptation strategies used to address the challenges. By gathering more evidence as well as addressing limitations identified in this study, the IEA is expected to serve as an analytical tool that facilitates the analysis of work-as-done (WAD) of complex team work and reconciling WAD with work-as-imagined (WAI) to promote resilience in emergency management. 

 

The second contribution from this study is the advancement of knowledge regarding the cognitive and decision-making processes of IMTs as a multidisciplinary team-of-teams. Historically, understanding cognition in an IMT has proven to be challenging, given its large size, nested structure, and multidisciplinary nature in addition to the elevated levels of uncertainty and time-pressure. By adopting a system-of-systems perspective and an interactive team cognition perspective, this project has provided a method for conceiving an IMT as a cognitive system-of-systems and conceptualizing its cognition as interactions within and between its sub-teams (component cognitive systems) to perceive (P), diagnose (D), and adapt (A) to information. Through a social network analysis of the observed interactions, three sub-teams of an IMT, i.e., Info/Intel, Situation, and Section Chief units, were identified as key components of an IMT?s cognition with their contributing roles of information collector, controller, and integrator. Then, interactions within and between those three component teams were transcribed and qualitatively analyzed, with the intention of understanding their contribution to the overall IMT?s system-level cognitive goals (P, D, and A). The PDA framework allows a holistic understanding of an IMT?s cognitive functioning and informs the future design of an IMT and its working environment from a macroergonomics perspective. 

 

The broader impacts of the results from this project apply to improving national security and infrastructure against threats from catastrophic disasters, which have caused billions of dollars in the US as well as worldwide. Given increasing importance of the roles that IMTs play during disasters, knowledge regarding the IMT?s interactive process for managing information will provide opportunities for future research investigations including the design of advanced emergency training programs and communication and decision support systems. Indeed, the combined results of the studies conducted under this project highlight practical points about IMTs as a system-of-systems that must engage in team cognition (as represented by PDA) and thus has important implications for training. For instance, although it is tempting to train each potential incident commanders or each unit (usually composed of about three to four incident commanders) separately, the true meaning of their training comes from understanding and experiencing their roles for the cognitive functioning of a larger system-of-systems. Further, it is with detailed analyses of the interactions associated with information management (available with the IEA), that teams? performance can be assessed with sufficient granularity and specificity for emergency operations training and research. Moreover, this project has also increased partnership between academia and government agencies (e.g., emergency operations training institute, state and municipal emergency operations centers) through collaborative efforts put in the design and implementation of multiple studies conducted under the project.
